chapters.title: Introduction
chapters.text: The addition of interest to the originally invested amount of a loan or deposit.

chapters.title: Relevance
chapters.text: Many banks use compounding to issue loans as well as a way to keep despoilers’ money at banks

chapters.title: Formula
chapters.text:
Formula: A = P( 1 + r/n))^nt

A = New principal sum

P = Original principal sum

r = Interest Rate (decimal)

n = Number of times interest is compounded per unit “t”

t = Time

chapters.title: Example
chapters.text:
Example: Suppose a principal amount of $1,00 is deposited in a bank paying an annual interest rate of 4.3%, compounded quarterly for 6 years.

P = 1500, 4 = 0.043 (4.3%), n = 4, t = 6

A = 1500*(1+0.043/4)^4*6 = 1938.84
